entry.title: Coos Bay man gets 20 years for fatal drunk driving crash
entry.summary: The driver involved in a tragic bus crash that claimed the lives of a softball coach and player has been sentenced to more than 20 years in prison.

entry.title: DFPA TO BEGIN ISSUING PERMITS FOR PRESCRIBED PASTURE BURNS
entry.summary: September 12, 2025 11:00 a.m. The Douglas Forest Protective Association will begin issuing permits for prescribed pasture burns as conditions permit. Public Information Officer Rachel Pope said such prescribed burns may be performed on fields and pastures to foster productive grazing lands for livestock and to enhance wildlife habitats. Pope said the primary aim of...

entry.title: DFPA to Issue Prescribed Pasture Burn Permits, Backyard Debris Burns Still Restricted
entry.summary: DFPA will issue permits for prescribed pasture burns to improve grazing lands and reduce wildfire risk. Backyard debris burning remains closed. Learn more about prescribed fire: https://extension.oregonstate.edu/collection/prescribed-fire-basics

entry.title: Dowdy Sentenced to More Than 20 Years for Fatal Crash Involving UCC Softball Team
entry.summary: Johnathan James Dowdy, 33, of Coos Bay, was sentenced to 20 years and six months in prison for the April 18 crash that killed UCC softball player Kiley Jones and head coach Jami Strinz, and injured teammates. Victims and families shared emotional statements during sentencing.

entry.title: An apple for every meal
entry.summary: If you've been searching for a unique way to declare your love to that special someone, take a tip from the ancient Greeks.

entry.title: 'Reptiles are better than people': How Sutherlin's Ragin Reptiles Supply grew to a nationwide pet provider
entry.summary: SUTHERLIN — If there’s one thing Kalee Duncan wants people to know about reptiles, it’s that they’re far from the cold-hearted, emotionless creatures they’re often portrayed as in media.

entry.title: Glide Revitalization awarded $10,000 from Oregon Community Foundation
entry.summary: GLIDE — In 2020, a series of wildifires across Oregon, dubbed the Labor Day Fires, laid waste to woodlands and the communities in them across Oregon. For Douglas County, that consisted of the Archie Creek Fire and its impacts to…

entry.title: Community Support Needed: Lookingglass Rural Fire District Seeks Grant for Lifesaving Cardiac Monitor
entry.summary: Lookingglass Rural Fire District is seeking community letters of support for a $15,000 Ford Family Foundation grant to help buy a Zoll X-Series Cardiac Monitor. The device will cut costs, speed patient transfers, and improve emergency care as call volumes rise. Email captain@lookingglassfire.org

entry.title: Judge rules Winchester Dam does not cause injury or death to coho salmon
entry.summary: U.S. District Court Judge Karin Immergut ruled Aug. 21 that the Winchester Dam is not directly or indirectly causing injury or death to Oregon Coast coho salmon.

entry.title: Mop-up on lightning-caused fires continues with varying containments

entry.title: Winston-Dillard Melon Festival Marks 56 Sweet Years of Tradition

entry.title: Five Years After the Flames: Archie Creek Fire’s Enduring Mark on Glide
entry.summary: September 9, 2025 marks five years since the Archie Creek Fire swept through Douglas County, burning 131,500 acres and destroying over 100 homes. Recovery continues as Glide reflects on loss, rebuilding, and resilience in the face of one of Oregon’s most devastating wildfires.

entry.title: Remembering Archie Creek: A picture's worth a thousand words
entry.summary: GLIDE — Tuesday marked five years since the French Creek and Star Mountain fires merged to become the Archie Creek fire.

entry.title: MORNING CONVERSATION 9.9.25
entry.summary: United Community Action Network Food Bank Manager Val Gordon and David Adamson from Columbia Bank talk about a food drive happening on Wednesday at Sherm’s Thunderbird Market.
